title: once partygate brings down boris
story: Once Partygate brings down Boris itll be our turn to throw a partyIts shocking that the investigation into lockdown-busting celebrations in Downing Street is costing us a fortune, but at least we should see the back of BorisWe cant wait to wave goodbye to PM Boris Johnson Image: Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Feb |commentsEviction from Downing Street will cost Boris Johnson his longed-for legacy. It will cost us, the taxpayer, £,. That’s the price of the civil service and police time spent probing No parties that should never have happened. The nation is rightly furious that the Prime Minister cared so little for the Covid rules he himself imposed that he put living it up before his duty to protect lives and livelihoods. Our PM gave not one jot about those who were forbidden from saying a final face-to-face goodbye to a dying loved one – or the family get-togethers we all did without because we were obeying his rules. Patsy Stevenson is angry too. She was fined £ for breaking lockdown restrictions to honour the memory of murdered Sarah Everard.  There was no cheese and wine at the vigil Patsy attended on London’s Clapham Common. Yet police pinned her down to arrest her, while ignoring food and booze pouring into No. The cost of the Partygate inquiry would be better spent on shielding women and girls from the kind of predator who snatched Sarah’s le away. And this investigation would not be needed had Mr Johnson and his staff accepted that rules also apply to them. This PM is on borrowed time. We will party – legally – when it finally runs out. A great honour for Camilla Camilla Parker Bowles may have been a skilled horsewoman, but she had a rough ride of it when she became Duchess of Cornwall. Many people could not forgive her for the part she played in the break-up of Prince Charles and Princess Diana’s marriage. But that was nothing compared to the fences the Queen had to jump within her own family while trying to maintain the dignity of royalty and respect for the monarchy. Both were tarnished when grandson Prince Harry turned his back on royal duties and skipped off to America to give a toe-curling interview to Oprah Winfrey, and strike ­embarrassing deals with Netflix.  It pained the Queen greatly when she had to strip her favourite son, Prince Andrew, of his titles as he faces accusations of sexual assault in a US court. But her duty to the nation demanded it, and the Queen has always put that before personal feelings. Throughout, Camilla has been steadfastly by the Queen’s side, her support in times of trouble. And just like the Sovereign, she negotiates the pathways of public le without putting a foot wrong – a ready smile and a kind word are always on her lips. The Queen is not one to ignore such loyalty and dedication. And today, as she becomes the first British monarch to reign for  years, she wants the world to know that when the time comes, Camilla will be called Queen Consort. We are delighted Camilla is to receive the honour. As they say in royal circles, she’s a jolly good fellow. And so say all of us. shared how she gets funny presents for the future king in a tribute to Princess Diana. Julia Samuel, who was friends with Diana, said the late princess started the tradition that the godparent should buy a gt for the children that was the most hilariously inconvenient and dficult to make.She shared her memories of the eccentric tradition in an episode of the podcast How to Fail with Elizabeth Day. “So I do to George what [Diana] did to us... which is give impossible toys which are really noisy, take a lot of making, she said.  “I come in slightly tipped by the size of the present that William then has to spend days putting together and then put all the machinery together. It makes awful tooting noises and lights flashing and all of that. That makes me laugh and it makes George laugh.”Ms Samuel spoke about how much Diana would have loved her grandchildren Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.The godmother, , said the young prince is amazing and that it is heartbreaking for all of them. “He’s funny and feisty and cheeky and God [Diana] would have loved him so much. That is heartbreaking for all of them,” she added.Ms Samuel, who is one of Prince George’s seven godparents, used to work in publishing before training as a counsellor, reports the Express.She met Diana at a dinner party in  and helped create Child Bereavement UK in .  The godmother received an MBE in  and now works as a bereavement counsellor in the paediatrics department at St Mary’s Hospital Paddington. Royal expert Katie Nicholl believes Prince William and Kate are careful when it comes to the presents they buy their children, despite living a le of privilege. They are regularly seen taking George, Charlotte and Louis on the school run and reportedly love doing fun activities such as baking, crafts and playing in the garden. title: queens historic message nation full
story: Queens historic message to the nation in full as she says Camilla will be QueenQueen Elizabeth, , said her reign has been a time of "extraordinary progress socially, technologically and culturally", and said she feels a "sense of hope and optimism" ahead of her Platinum Jubilee.The Queen assumed the throne following the death of her father in  Image: PAByLaura ElstonDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Feb |commentsThe Queen has issued a celebratory message to her subjects as she marks  years as head of state. The monarch, , said her reign has been a time of extraordinary progress socially, technologically and culturally, and said she feels a sense of hope and optimism ahead of her Platinum Jubilee. The longest-serving monarch in British history said she will be eternally grateful for, and humbled by, the loyalty and affection that you continue to give me. She also voiced her confidence that her son Charles and his we Camilla would be given the same support you have given me.She paid an emotional tribute to Prince Philip, saying he was a partner willing to carry out the role of consort and unselfishly make the sacrices that go with it. Here is the Queenaposs statement in full Tomorrow, th February, marks the th anniversary of my Accession in . It is a day that, even after  years, I still remember as much for the death of my father, King George VI, as for the start of my reign. As we mark this anniversary, it gives me pleasure to renew to you the pledge I gave in  that my le will always be devoted to your service. As I look ahead with a sense of hope and optimism to the year of my Platinum Jubilee, I am reminded of how much we can be thankful for. These last seven decades have seen extraordinary progress socially, technologically and culturally that have benefitted us all and I am confident that the future will offer similar opportunities to us and especially to the younger generations in the United Kingdom and throughout the Commonwealth. I am fortunate to have had the steadfast and loving support of my family. I was blessed that in Prince Philip I had a partner willing to carry out the role of consort and unselfishly make the sacrices that go with it. It is a role I saw my own mother perform during my fatheraposs reign. This anniversary also affords me a time to reflect on the goodwill shown to me by people of all nationalities, faiths and ages in this country and around the world over these years.  I would like to express my thanks to you all for your support. I remain eternally grateful for, and humbled by, the loyalty and affection that you continue to give me. And when, in the fullness of time, my son Charles becomes King, I know you will give him and his we Camilla the same support that you have given me and it is my sincere wish that, when that time comes, Camilla will be known as Queen Consort as she continues her own loyal service. And so as I look forward to continuing to serve you with all my heart, I hope this Jubilee will bring together families and friends, neighbours and communities - after some dficult times for so many of us - in order to enjoy the celebrations and to reflect on the positive developments in our day-to-day lives that have so happily coincided with my reign. Your Servant Elizabeth R. The Queen also met former cookery school student Angela Wood who helped to perfect the famous dish coronation chicken served to guests after the Queenaposs  Coronation ceremony. But February , the date of the Queenaposs accession to the throne, is a poignant period for the Queen, as it is the day her father King George VI died in . She is already the nationaposs longest reigning monarch, and the longest still-serving sovereign in the world. During the reception the Queen also met representatives from West Norfolk Befriending a charity which aims to reduce the social isolation experienced by the elderly by matching them with trained volunteer befrienders who visit on a regular basis.  And she spoke to members of Little Discoverers which provides early education for pre-school children with movement dficulties and delayed development. When the Queen was presented with a copy of a Loyal Address written by primary schoolchildren from West Norfolk the head of state gave a frank opinion on public proclamations she has heard during her long reign. story: I ate Icelands frozen Slimming World meals for a week - this is what happenedManchester Evening News reporter Dianne Bourne dined on Icelands frozen Slimming World meals for a whole week to find out how effective they were, and the results are inDianne Bourne tried Icelands Slimming World ready meals to find outthey worked Image: MENByJohn BettAudience WriterDianne Bourne:,  Feb |comments With the year still being young and New Years Resolutions still ringing in our ears, many people around the country will still be trying to stick to their diet and exercise regimes. But dieting can be tough, and who has the time to plan out dferent healthy meals for each day of the week  Now, Iceland has you covered. The frozen food giant has teamed up with Slimming World to sell a series of meals that are designed to help you lose weight, but are they any good  Intrepid journalist Dianne Bourne, from the Manchester Evening News, has now put her tastebuds on the line as she dined out on seven meals from the range - and documented the effect on her weight loss.What do you think of the frozen Slimming World meals  Let us know in the comments... Day Chicken tikka and rice lunch bowl - £. Dianne said: A great way to kick off the week of taste tests - with one of the lunch bowl meals - designed, as the title suggests, as a lighter daytime option. This is a new one to the range and I enjoyed what was a satisfying mix of crunchy vegetables, rice and tasty tikka-coated chicken pieces which was also pretty filling. Rating:   Chicken carbonara - £.  Dianne said: I was not holding out much hope for this one as it smelt slightly unpleasant as it cooked away in the microwave. Billed as a aposcomforting pasta dish with seared chicken, smoky pork strips, mushroom and spinach in a white sauceapos it did not look all that inspiring or comforting when I poured it into my dish. There were around eight pieces of chicken and a few strips of pork, and my first thought was that it seemed to taste very salty and the consistency was a bit gloopy. For me, I think Iaposd rather stick with making my own carbonara - as the Slimming World versionis a fairly simple and much cheaper recipe to make from scratch. Rating:    Day  Caullower and chick pea dahl - £. Dianne said: This can be eaten on its own or as a side dish. It probably would have been better as a side dishIaposm honest as I found it a bit unfulfilling as a lunch dish. It had a pleasant curry hit though and I like the crunch of the caullower with the chickpeas. Rating:   Chilli Con Carne - £.  Dianne said: A really hearty dish with large chunks of meat in a rich sauce and the rice was nicely herbed up. If you werenapost doing Slimming World youaposd think this was just a regular chilli ready meal, which is probably the best compliment I can give it. Indeed, my friendaposs strapping -year-old lad aposaccidentallyapos microwaved himself one of these and gave it a big thumbs up as well, so itaposs definitely good in the aposgenerous portionapos stakes. Rating:   Day  Cowboy hotpot - £.  Dianne said: Itaposs safe to say this was the dish I was most looking forward to. I mean, it has cowboy in its title and sausages and potato in it so whataposs not to love  Well, unfortunately the dish itself was what I could not learn to love. It said on the packet it was best cooked in the oven and I followed the cooking times to the tee, but it came out very dry and stodgy. It just did nothing for me at all - the sausages were firm and dry and the potatoes also had a powdery consistency on top. So disappointed with this one, definitely not a yee-ha moment from me. Rating:   Beef vindaloo - £.  Dianne said: However, tea time well and truly gave me one of the highlights of the week - in the new beef vindaloo dish. This was a real treat. A really brilliant hit of spices in a rich tomato sauce with flavoursome lumps of beef. Rating:   Day  Moroccan style chicken soup - £. Dianne said: Again, a very off-putting smell from the microwave, but once cooked this one was pretty delicious. A really interesting spice mix with a decent amount of heat, and lots of pulled chicken which made this one a warming and filling soup dish that I would definitely buy again. Rating:   Beef Lasagne - £.  Dianne said: This one has been a favourite of many SW-ers for a while now, but theyaposve just introduced a new recipe. So it is as good as the old one  Well, I was pretty excited about this one - because itaposs even better. The new recipe has finally nailed the elusive creamy cheesy aspect of the lasagne that is not easy to do.  Taking a nosy at the recipe card on the inside, it appears to be a mixture of butternut squash, potato and the magic Quark that has created the delightful crispy cheesy topping here. A word of warning on this one though - while it can be cooked in the microwave, it does say for best results stick in the oven. And, while it does take a mammoth  minutes, it tastes sooo much better this way to get that cheesy crunch. Rating:    Day  Naked beef burrito - £. Dianne said: A good amount of spice kick in this one, and itaposs quite a satisfying lunch pot. If you have your HEA of cheese available I feel like it would be nicer with this mixed in - I added some peppers and salad on the side. Rating:   Hunteraposs chicken - £.  Dianne said: This one has to be cooked in the oven and is a large portion for two, so my other half got roped into eating this one with me. It had a long cooking time of over an hour this one - and Iaposm not surethataposs why the chicken was a bit dry and chewy. And oneaposs thing for sure, it looked absolutely nothing like the glossy image on the packaging when it came out of my oven. But the overall flavour was ok - although the barbecue sauce was a tad on the watery side. My feeling is this one would be much easier and better to simply recreate yourself at home - itaposs just a rasher of bacon plonked on some chicken really. Rating:    Day  Colcannon Mash - £ Dianne said: Running a bit out of options at this stage, I decide to try the colcannon mash which I team with steamed broccoli and salmon. The mash is, like a lot of the meals, a tad on the salty side but teams well with salmon and I like that you can taste the cabbage in the mash mix. This is a convenient one to have in the freezer for those moments you canapost be bothered making your own mash. Rating:   Smoky meatball tray bake with potato wedges - £  Dianne said: The meatballs were on the dry side, but had a decent flavour punch, and were extremely pleasant when mushed together with all the smoky tomato and chickpea sauce. There was a decent size portion for two of us, although we did add lots of vegetables for speed. This was a really tasty one - but Iaposm afraid it canapost get full marks this one for the sheer faff factor. It took hr and mins to cook in the oven which comes in very low on the convenience factor - as does the vast size of the packet that I needed to try and wodge in my not very sizeable freezer. Itaposs also pretty expensive for this style of dish. Rating:   Day  Slimming World chips - £. Dianne said: Itaposs the last day, so Iaposm going all out with the curry and chips on the menu. And thereaposs literally nothing  left to eat. So I bung some of the frozen chips in the oven and serve them with some baked beans. Now with these frozen chips, people either love them or hate them from my experience at Slimming World group.  I have personally perfected a good flavour by sprinkling some syn-free spice on them and then spraying them with low-calorie spray. They do have a slightly strange consistency, but they are a convenient option to have ready-made in the freezer when you canapost face peeling and chopping up potatoes and cooking from scratch. Rating:   Chicken tikka rogan josh - £.  Dianne said: Ending the week on a high with this classic curry. The Slimming World chicken tikka masala has been a bit of a staple since the Iceland range was first launched, but this new rogan josh version might even trump it for me. Loved the spice on this one, and the added lumps of tomato and pepper. You could almost be eating a aposrealapos takeaway curry. Rating:   Did it work  Dianne said: Well, this is the big question isnapost it  After a whole week of eating the ready meals, and sticking  per cent to the Slimming World plan throughout the rest of the day, Iaposd have been guttedI didnapost lose any weight. But guess what  I did. I lost a whopping lbs. Which just goes to show sticking to aposfree foodsapos and the rest of the rules of the Slimming World plan does do the trick.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. But with all of the added expenses that having a baby will bring, itaposs wise to really think about what you want to splurge on and where you can save some money. Thankfully, one mum has done some of the hard work for you and has shared a few baby items that probably donapost need to buy.Frances Chie regularly shares parenting tips and tricks on her TikTok @lovefranceschieein order to help other people navigate parenthood.In a recent video, that has been viewed more than . million times, she revealed four baby items that are a big waste of money - and some might surprise you. story: Women are just discovering why their shirts button on the left and not rightWomens blouses tend to button on the left, while mens shirts are more likely to have fastenings along the right-hand side – and theres an interesting reason whyWomens shirts button on the left, but why  Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJohn BettAudience WriterBillie Schwab DunnFeatures Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments It has been an interesting year of discovery for women - more specically, womenaposs clothes - as two stories emerged explaining why they are dferent to menaposs clothing.Now internet sleuths have turned their attention to shirts, and why the buttons on womenaposs are on the opposite side to menaposs.As the Daily Star reports, there are a iety of theories as to why this may be the case, and one dates back to when men were locked in battle, and another theory is to do with child-rearing.Melanie M. Moore, founder of womenaposs blouse brand Elizabeth  Clarke, has a dferent theory and thinks she may have unearthed the reason once and for all. Why do you think womenaposs blouses button on the opposite side to menaposs shirts  Let us know in the comments...One thoery is that menaposs shirts had buttons on the right side because most men held their swords in their right hand. This meant they needed to be able to unbutton their shirt quickly to duel and unbuttoning using their left hand was faster. As to why womenaposs buttons are on the left, many believe itaposs because women tend to carry their babies in their left arms.  Itaposs possible that womenaposs shirts were designed to be opened or closed with the free right hand to make breastfeeding easier, so they were buttoned on the left and open on the right. It also may be because way back when women were expected to ride horses sidesaddle. Buttoning up on the left may have kept the breeze from blowing up their shirts as they galloped across fields.  Another possible explanation for the iation in button placement could be traced back to the rise of emancipation when women began to abandon their girdles in favour of pants and other traditionally male clothes. As a practical technique of distinguishing between menaposs and womenaposs clothing, manufacturers placed buttons on the left side of womenaposs clothing. Melanie M. Moore, founder of womenaposs blouse brand Elizabeth  Clarke, has a dferent theory. When buttons were invented in the th century they were, like most new technology, very expensive, she told Today. Wealthy women back then did not dress themselves — their ladyaposs maid did. Since most people were right-handed, this made it easier for someone standing across from you to button your dress. There are a iety of possible reasons as to why menaposs and womenaposs shirts are buttoned dferently. At this point though, it all comes down to good old-fashioned tradition.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: over 100 british elite troops
story: Exclusive: Over  British elite troops sent to Ukraine amid fears of imminent Russian invasionPrime Minister Boris Johnson and French President Emmanuel Macron today agreed countries on Natos eastern flank should be "fully defended against malicious Russian activity"The specialist forces are believed to be helping train Ukrainian special forces in counter-insurgency tactics, sniping and sabotage Image: GettyByDan WarburtonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsMore than  members of Britain’s elite special forces have been sent to Ukraine amid fears a Russian invasion is imminent. Crack troops from the SAS, the SBS, the Special Reconnaissance Regiment and the Special Forces Support group are understood to be working in the country as military advisers. They are believed to be helping train Ukrainian special forces in counter-insurgency tactics, sniping and sabotage. British special forces have been able to deploy such a large number to the region as they are no longer operating in Afghanistan. Although the SAS and SBS are still in Syria and Iraq, the numbers of troops there are believed to be relatively small.  A source said: “UK special forces have been deployed to the region to help and advise the Ukrainian military. They have a wide skill set which will no doubt be very useful to the Ukrainian forces.” At least , winter-trained British troops are also now based in Estonia, which borders Russia.Meanwhile, Russia has started equipping dozens of military field hospitals close to its border with Ukraine, fuelling fears of an imminent invasionIntelligence sources say doctors, nurses and medical supplies – including thousands of litres of blood and plasma – have arrived in the region, where fighting would be the most intense. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. NowHelensburghMore than  houses will be built on the site of Helensburgh Golf Cluban application submitted to Argyll and Bute Council is approved.Taylor Wimpey officially applied for planning permission at the site on East Abercromby Street in the latter part of , and the application has now been validated by Argyll and Bute Council and published on the authority’s website.As well as  residential units the plans also include demolition of the golf club’s existing clubhouse, the building of a new clubhouse and the provision of an enhanced -hole golf course.Feedback can now be given title: lochgilphead composer creates new islay symphony
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe Royal Scottish National Orchestra has recorded a new symphony written by a Lochgilphead composer who was inspired by the beauty of Islay.The Rinns of Islay, composed by Helen MacKinnon, is a -minute symphony that portrays #a musical journey around the Inner Hebridean island#, which was home to the composer’s grandparents and generations before.Inspired by stories of Islay in her youth, Helen began sketching the work during her composition studies at The University of Glasgow and ed to complete the work nearly  years later.The -minute piece for symphony orchestra was recorded in Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, with American-based PARMA Recordings and GRAMMY-winning producer Brad Michel.Helen, who grew up in Lochgilphead. explained: #It was a privilege to record with Scotland’s national orchestra.#The musicians and conductor, David Watkin, breathed glorious le into the work, which takes us on a musical journey around the island.#Due to Covid, we had a cross-Atlantic recording team, with technology connecting a producer in Boston with a team on the ground in Glasgow. It was a fascinating experience.#The new orchestral work was inspired by Islay’s stunning natural environment, known for its rich terrain and peaty whisky.Five short thematic movements celebrate Islay’s sunrises and coastal shores, while giving a playful nod to the island’s abundant whisky industry.Helen added: #The work centres around The Rinns – a beautul peninsula overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.#My father used to talk about The Rinns of Islay, and as a child, I started to create stories and soundscapes linked to the island.#The work offers a visual, almost cinematic listening experience, with atmospheres and landmarks inspiring the visual imagination.#The work features on a new album Legends and Light Vol. , featuring works by seven composers.While many of the pieces are arranged for orchestral ensembles, listeners will also find the Highland bagpipes and Irish Uilleann pipes featured on the album, offering a deeply rewarding listening experience.Helen is delighted with feedback so far: #I’m thrilled with audiences’ responses to the music.#Listeners have tuned in from across the UK, the USA and as far afield as New Zealand, keeping Scotland on the international map for new music.#

title: debut-goal-new-gala-fairydean-rovers-signing
story: MARTIN Scott believes that Gala Fairydean Rovers’ attacking philosophy will suit new signing Scott Cusick’s style and he will be a good addition to the squad.The Glaswegian came off the bench to score the winner against Dalbeattie Star on Saturday but had to be replaced late on after ‘working his socks off.’Scott said: “We just brought Scotty in recently who was available as a free agent. I had actually played with Scotty when he was on loan at Brechin City from Dunfermline, so I knew what he was capable of. I knew he would fit into our philosophy and how we want to play the game.“My intention was to give him - minutes, but he came on early and worked his socks off and got his reward with the goal and then we had to being him back off because his legs had just went at that point.“He probably needs a bit more game time in terms of match fitness and sharpness but when he gets up to full speed, he will be a real asset for us.“We went short-term and this gives him a chance to get back playing and enjoying his football. And it gives us the opportunity to let him see what we are about and come the end of the season we will probably assess that again.“Everyone knows Gala is a great club. I think that little bit of professionalism and trying to do things in the right manner will help bring him on. He came down and trained with us and as soon as he met the chairman and the boys make everyone feel welcome when they come to the club .“There is a real togetherness there so I think it will suit Scotty going forward so it’s up to him what he does from here until the end of the season. I told him that he will get an opportunity to play but he needs to show me that he’s here to contribute.“He has a good pedigree at Dunfermline and Celtic as a kid and he’s got a good attitude but has just lost his way a bit in terms of going on loan to Brechin City when they were in League Two. It was a tough ask to come in and play men’s football when they were just desperate for results. So it probably wasn’t the ideal fit for him. Going forward, coming to us will suit him as he has an eye for a pass and an eye for a goal and is comfortable on both feet. He can go outside or inside and has a bit of pace. He’ll be a really good addition. “

title: natural-beauty-history-borders-inspires-photographers
story: A COLOURFUL image of sheep grazing on the purple heather of The Gypsy Glen in the Tweed Valley has been ranked by VisitScotland as the most popular Scottish Borders social media post of .The photograph by @becky__ received more than , likes when it was shared by the national tourism organisation on its Instagram account, making it the highest performing post of the region last year.An image of Sir Walter Scott’s ancestral home at Abbotsford House near Melrose was ranked second most popular post for the region. The image, which was captured by @flordeescocia and received more than , likes, shows the stunning Baronial property through an open gate from the surrounding landscaped gardens.The third highest performing post was by photographer Martin Donald Smithwho captured an atmospheric image of the dark skies above Smailholm Tower that attracted more than , likes.Between January  and January , VisitScotland’s Instagram reached people over  million times with  user-generated posts. The channel has played an important role in keeping Scotland front of mind and inspiring potential visitors during the global pandemic.VisitScotland launched its global marketing campaign Scotland is Calling last year, aimed specically at overseas visitors who, research suggests, spend longer planning and researching their trips.VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director Paula Ward said: “The wide-open spaces, natural beauty and history of the Scottish Borders are a fantastic source of inspiration for photographers and these images have captured some of the many reasons visitors are drawn to the region.“VisitScotland’s social media channels have played an important role in the last two years in continuing to keep Scotland front of mind and offering inspiration to our global audiences for when they can travel. We know there is pent-up demand for travel and we want to ensure that we inspire potential visitors with what Scotland has to offer and make it their first-choice destination when they can travel..remove“Tourism is a force for good – creating economic and social value in every corner of Scotland and enhancing the wellbeing of everyone who experiences it. Tourism makes Scotland richer, economically and socially, and without it Scotland would be a much poorer place.”Abbotsford Trust Chief Executive Giles Ingram said: “We are thrilled that this stunning shot of Abbotsford was such a popular image in . It gives you a sneak-peak into the glorious walled gardens, with Scott’s “conundrum castle” beyond.“Social media has been invaluable to our charity over the past couple of years, allowing us to bring the experience of Abbotsford to people in their own home. We have been delighted to see visitor numbers begin to recover in  and look forward to welcoming more visitors to Abbotsford as we celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott throughout .”

title: council-seeks-views-lockdown-traffic-measures
story: BORDERERS are asked to give their feedback on the trial traffic measures introduced since the start of the pandemic.In  Scottish Borders Councilintroduced the trial  mph limits in between Lauder and Earlston, and between Heriot Stow Fountainhall and Clovenfords and restricted road access on the Caddonfoot Road .Now the local authority wants locals views on the programme of measures andthey should be made permanent.“The COVID- pandemic and the resulting lockdowns provided the Council with the perfect opportunity to trial ious measures that had the potential to make our roads safer whilst also encouraging more exercise and active travel," said councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport at SBC.For the areas where temporary  mph limits were introduced, SBC wants to determinepermanent signage should be installed orthe stretches of road shouldto the national speed limit.Restricted access was added to the Caddonfoot Road on July , , to increase pedestrian access to the playing field and to be safer for exercise.Due to the insufficient space on the verge for a pavement, SBC wants to hear about peoples experiences and seethere is a demand for allowing vehicles on the road again orit should be kept closed.Mr Edgar said: “Now is the right time to reassess these measures and we are extremely keen for as many people as possible to share their views to help determine the future of these backroads.”Surveys for both the  mph speed limits and Caddonfoot Road are now live and will be open until February .The  mph speed limit trial survey can be found at:www.scotborders.gov.uk mphconsultationAnd the survey for Caddonfoot Road can be accessed at:www.scotborders.gov.uk caddonfootroadconsultation

title: scotland-20s-six-nations-opener-live-bbc-iplayer
story: This will be a proud weekend for the Borders town of Hawick with Stuart Hogg captaining Scotland against the Auld Enemy England tomorrow in the Calcutta Cup match at BT Murrayfield and Rhys Tait doing likewise for the Us tonight at the DAM Health Stadium.Boroughmuir Bear Tait leads Scotland out for the first time from openside flanker as the age-grade sideto play in Scotland for the first time since February .Born and raised in Hawick, Tait started his rugby career at Jed-Forest Minis aged  years old and has already represented Scotland at U and U age-grade level.Tait will be joined in the back row by Matt Deehanwho will make his first appearance in the squad at blindside flanker and Exeter University’s Ollie Leatherbarrow at No  who featured in all five of Scotland’s games last year.Edinburgh Rugby’s Patrick Harrison who enjoyed a successful spell with the Southern Knights last year will start at hooker and will pack down alongside Tom Bantavalaand Currie Chieftains Gregor Scougall who s from injury to take his place in the squad and is set to make his first Scotland U appearance.The imposing figure of Max Williamsonwillto the squad in the second-row and will be joined by Josh Taylor from Ealing Trailfinders.Behind the scrum Jed Gelderbloomstarts at scrum-half and will partner Ayrshire Bulls, and Glasgow Warriors, Christian Townsend at stand-off.It’s an all Boroughmuir Bears mid-field as Mike Gray starts at inside-centre and Duncan Munn at outside him. title: prime-minister-not-law-says-borders-mp
story: TWO Conservative Borders politicians are united in their belief that Sue Gray’s report should be published in full and that the British public have a right to see the evidence for themselves.When allegations first emerged of parties in Downing Street, Prime Minister Boris Johnson told parliament he had obeyed all lockdown rules.Subsequent evidence showed he had personally attended what appeared to be social events.Civil Servant Sue Gray was tasked with investigating the circumstances and was expected to produce a comprehensive report.However last week the politan Police launched a parallel investigation which resulted in a heavily edited version of her report being published. This sparked a furious debate in the House of Commons.No guarantee was given by the Prime Minister that an unredacted report would be made available to MPs.In response Borders MP John Lamont said: “It is deeply frustrating that Sue Gray has been unable to release her full report so that we can see the full facts of what has gone on. The country has a right to see the evidence for themselves and it must be published in full when the police investigation concludes.”MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale David Mundell said: “The document which has been presented by Sue Gray is an update on her investigation into alleged gatherings on Government premises during Covid restrictions. It details a number of alleged gatherings, all but four of which are now subject to a separate investigation by the politan Police and, as a result, details of those events have not been reported in the update in order not to prejudice the police investigations.“My strong view is that, when it is possible, the report in its entirety should be published, as I believe everyone has a right to see what has been established.”Both also insisted that anyone found to have broken the lawshould be held accountable.Mr Lamont added: “No one is above the law. Not even the Prime Minister. Those found to have broken the law must be held accountable.”.removeMr Mundell said: “Equally, should the ongoing police investigation conclude that there is evidence warranting proceedings against any of the iniduals involved, then those proceedings must be taken forward as they would against any other member of the public.”

title: coronavirus-borders-pcr-test-site-close-next-month
story: THE only site for coronavirus PCR tests in the Borders will close next month, a meeting has heard.Senior councillor Gordon Edgar said the local authority has served a notice, on behalf of Live Borders, on the UK Health Security Agency to vacate the community centre in Langlee.The news comes after concerns were raised that residents were being ‘deprived’ of a vital hub.NHS Borders says it is “exploring other options for PCR testing provision” in the region.:Borders Railway extension project dead in the water, says transport chiefMr Edgar – the executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport – told the meeting: “Scottish Borders Council served notice on behalf of Live Borders on the UK Health Security Agency to vacate by March , . They have advised that the site will cease testing on March ,  and will be demobilised.”Mr Edgar said last year that the current lease was set to expire in January, but the UK Government asked that the PCR test sites remain operational until March.Galashiels councillor Harry Scott said that “many groups” have been forced to evacuate the centre due to its use as a PCR testing site.“This centre is located in one of the areas where it houses some of the poorest and most disadvantaged in our community and the loss of the facility has had a great effect,” he said.:Borders politicians want Sue Grays report to be published in fullFollowing concerns raised by Mr Scott over reported damage to the floor at the centre, Mr Edgar confirmed that any necessary reinstatement work would be carried out.An NHS Borders spokesperson said: “Currently PCR tests are available via the walk-through site at Langlee Community Centre, a Mobile Testing Unitwhich circulates between strategic sites in the Borders and home delivery by ordering online or calling .“We are exploring other options for PCR testing provision in the Borders, in line with national directives, and discussions with local partner organisations are ongoing.”.removeThe centre’s testing facility and MTU are both provided by the UK Government’s Department of Health and Social Care.

title: hawick-woman-obtained-8k-benefits-not-entitled
story: A BORDERS woman who obtained more than £, in benefits she was not entitled to has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Thirty-eight-year-old Carrie Whillans, of Harwood Cottage, Hawick, received £, in income support and also £, in housing benefit between September  and December  she was not entitled to as she was residing with her partner at the time.Defence lawyer Ross Dow said his client had an on-off relationship with her partner at the time.He added she was in process of repaying the money.Whillans was given nine months to complete the unpaid work.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-borders-tariff-rates-approved
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council’s leader has spoken of his aspiration to have charging points for electric vehicles outside “every village hall” across the region.Mark Rowley, of the Conservatives, was speaking at a meeting last week where elected members approved tarf rates for the facilities.Charging points had been free in the region thanks to Transport Scotland funding.However, rates at p per kWh for ‘rapid’ charge points and p per kWh for ‘destination’ charge points have been backed.At the meeting, Mr Rowley, a Mid Berwickshire councillor, said: “There’s huge aspiration here. We need to get charging points into the right places.“My aspiration would be to see charging points outside every village hall right across the Borders.”SBC’s regime will see the introduction of an overstay charge, a minimum charge of £ per session and a p connection surcharge between pm-pm to ease demand on the electricity grid at peak times.An SBC report states: “Based on usage figures for  this gives a potential income in the region of £, a year, creating a surplus of around £, a year to contribute towards maintaining the current infrastructure.“This excludes overstay charges which would also generate additional surplus and would also allow scope to absorb any small increases in energy prices without the need to constantly alter the tarf.”A feasibility study has been commissioned, funded through the Community Renewal Fund, to undertake “a region-wide, cross-sector assessment of supply, demand and commercial opportunities to create a strategic delivery model for EV charging infrastructure”.At the meeting, Tweeddale West councillor Heather Anderson, of the SNP, said: “It’s great news there’s going to be an electric vehicle feasibility study to look at how we get private sector investment equitably across the region despite the disperse nature of our rural population.“It’s absolutely essential that the private sector don’t cherry pick the most financially viable sites and leave the other sites without any sort of provision.”.removeSBC’s current EV infrastructure consists of  chargers across  dferent towns and villages, according to the report.A November meeting was told that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was £,.Supporting the proposed tarf rates, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott said it was “a nonsense” that the council provides the service for free and that the local authority should “benefit commercially from the use of these machines”.He added: “There has to be a certain amount of caution before we go down this road because the tech seems to gallop on quite signicantly and what we don’t want to be doing is spending £-, installing a machine that might be redundant in a year’s time, so it’s right that the officers keep an eye on this.”

title: music-peebles-marks-75th-year-popular-quartet
story: is a big milestone in the history of Music in Peebles.The group is marking its th season since its formationin .It is also a big year for their very special guests in February, the Brodsky Quartet.An appearance by the group is always an eagerly-awaited highlight, but this appearance is all the more special for being part of the quartets th anniversary celebrations.Coincidentally, the Brodsky Quartet last came to Peebles in , while marking their th anniversary.The programme for the night starts with Borodin Scherzo in D for String Quartet, followed by Schubert String Quartet No. in A minor, D. , James MacMillan “For Sonny” and “Memento” and Shostakovich String Quartet No. in E flat, Op..The concert culminates in the enigmatic th Quartet by Shostakovich, a composer with whose music the Brodsky Quartet is particularly associated.Paul Cassidy, the groups violist, describes the th as “one of the most exhilarating of the whole cycle” ending with “one of the greatest finales of the string quartet literature. Indeed one of the most exciting pieces of music I know”.In the words of the great Michael Tumelty, writing in the Herald: “The Brodsky Quartet is not just a great group. It is a genuine phenomenon”.The show takes place on Sunday  February from .pm - pm.Tickets are available from the Eastgate Theatre box office on   and www.eastgatearts. title: youngsters-help-keep-roads-safe-around-school
story: KELSOs Junior Road Safety Officers were out in force this week helping police to carry out speed checks outside Broomlands Primary School.On Wednesday the youngsters joined officers from the Scottish Borders Police Community Action Team to deter speeders and help keep the roads safe.One of the Scottish Borders Local Policing Priorities is to Improving Road Safety and the Community Action Team are funded by the Scottish Borders Council to deal with local issues such as this.The JRSOs and their teams are a huge help to the Road Safety Officer for the local area, as they help promote road safety issues within the school and local community.More than % of primary schools in Scotland now have JRSOs and their ethos is one of pupil empowerment and partnership working to enable children to become successful learners, confident iniduals, responsible citizens and effective contributors.They talk at assemblies and to classes on road safety topics, run competitions in the school, get prizes for the winners and hand out merit certicates, write letters and get involved in organising safe and active travel activities.JSRO’s are normally Primary  pupils, or pupils at the end of Primary , who apply for the job by filling in an application form stating they have to say why they would like the job and what would make them a good JRSO.The applicants may then be asked to attend an interview. The interview  can be made up of the JRSOs who are finishing and a teacher and or the JRSO Co-ordinator.Once they have been appointed, the JRSOs will receive their own Personal JRSO Organiser, which includes some useful advice, a badge, pen and name card.Some schools involve other pupils by having Assistants or Deputes to form a JRSO team to help the lead JRSOs.

title: martin-lewis-cheaper-switch-heating-off-leave-running
story: Martin Lewiss MoneySavingExpert has revealed how to use your central heating. Britain’s cost of living crisis intensied on Thursday as Ofgem announced rise in the maximum price of home energy bills by up to  per cent above current record highs.The energy regulator has announced the new energy bill price cap will rise by  per cent per cent from April.It means energy prices will rise by £ a year for millions of households after regulator Ofgem hiked the price cap on bills to £,.Officials across Whitehall have been locked in talks with industry bosses for months and the watchdog Ofgem to draw together a set of measures which could cushion households against rocketing energy bills and a cost of living crisis.The idea that its cheaper to leave the heating on low all day is a myth And people will be wondering how to use their central heating in a cost-effective way.According to experts at the Energy Saving Trust, the idea that its cheaper to leave the heating on low all day is a myth.Martin Lewis has stepped in and revealed exactly how to use your central heatingto get the best value out of it."Having the heating on only when you need it is, in the long run, the best way to save energy, and therefore money," his MoneySavingExpert website explains.SEE ALSO: ​Martin Lewis explains how to reduce cost of heating bills"A timers best as your thermostat turns your heating on and off to keep your home at the temperature you set."The key thing to understand here is that its all about the total amount of energy required to heat your home."However, people living in places where its damp might have to turn the central heating on for longer.Martin added: "There are some engineers who argue that keeping the heating on low with all the radiators on and the boiler down can work as it reduces condensation, which when the heating is turned off collects within the walls, and can help conduct heat outside the home - meaning you lose heat more quickly and so will lose heat more quickly and will use more energy as a result..removeSEE ALSO: Martin Lewis warning to shoppers who pay with cash"Soyour house is prone to that you may want to think about it."The Energy Saving Trust saysyoure keeping the heating on all day youre losing energy all day, so its better to heat your home only when you need it.You can also apply for a Cold Weather Payment to help when temperatures fall to freezing, a Warm Home Discount or a Winter Fuel Payment to minimise your bills.Six more ways to cut your heating bill:Shut the blinds and windowsMany people get complacent over the summer months and forget to shut them – go round the house and make sure that no cold air is getting in anywhere.If the sun is shining in the daytime then make sure curtains and blinds are open to let the heat in, but ensure that you shut them in the morning and the evenings to give yourself that extra bit of warmth.Close off unused roomsUnused rooms can be taking in a lot of heat, as well as increasing the amount of cool breeze flowing through your house. By closing them off, you will cut out the draught and also ensure that any heat in your property isn’t escaping into that room.Get draught excludersA big reason why your home may not be retaining heat very well is because of draughts.Allowing cold air to get into the home will bring the overall temperature down.SEE ALSO: ​House-warming hacks to help keep the heating bill downIf you can stop these draughts from getting in, it will make a huge dference to the temperature in your home.Get cookingEating hot food will help to warm you up and the process of cooking the food will throw heat out into the kitchen and surrounding areas, meaning your home will warm up as a result.Consider getting rugsIf your house is fully carpeted, then you needn’t worry about this option, as that will help insulate your home.However, you can lose a considerable amount of heat through floorboards or tiles, so putting a rug over the top can make all the dference in your home’s heat retention.Put tin foil behind your radiatorIf on the occasion you do have the heating on, which you should because it is good for home’s condition, then you should put foil behind your radiators to make sure the heat is forced into the room, rather than getting lost in the wall.

title: sleeping-difficulties-two-foods-avoid
story: Foodsthat could be causing trouble with your sleep have been revealed.Two foods in particular have been highlighted by experts for impacting your ability to sleep.If Onions and tomatoes feature regularly in your diet and you struggle to get to sleep at night, this could be why.Onions and tomatoes affect your ability to sleepOnions can cause issues with your digestions system with the ability to create acid reflux issues and in turn affecting your sleep.The same warning applies for tomatoes.Eating onions regularly can increase likelihood of heartburn which can create reflux when you lie down.The Sleep Association said warned: "Onions create gas as they move through your digestive system.”They added: "That gas affects the pressure within your stomach, which can send acid back up your oesophagus, especially when you’re lying down flat."Sadly, both raw and grilled onions have this effect."" alt"Border :Onions and tomatoes could be affecting your sleep. " class"editor-image"Onions and tomatoes could be affecting your sleep.What foods to eat for better sleepDue to the fact onions and tomatoes take longer to digest than others which can keep you up all night.It’s worth considering other foods that act as more natural sedatives.Nuts are considered to be good foods for promoting sleep including almonds, walnuts, pistachios, and cashews.For those who enjoy a warm drink at night, camomile tea could also boost your chances of nodding off at a reasonable time.

title: new-biking-festival-set-arrive-peeblesshire
story: HUNDREDS of people will finally arrive in Peeblesshire for a new biking festival this year – two years later than planned.The enduro-style event will take place between April -May  in the grounds of landmark Traquair House.Muck n’ Mac Festival, the brainchild of Cameron Balfour, was initially planned for July  but suffered two years of setbacks due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, the -year-old says he is “excited” for his work to finally come to fruition.“We started doing the work on it in  and we were initially meant to be having it in July , but obviously with COVID we had to reschedule it,” said Cameron, who was part of Peebles Cycling Club as a kid. “We rescheduled it to last year and then it fell again when we were in a heavy lockdown.“It’s just been such a long period of work on it, I’m just excited to see it all together in one finished product.“It’s been knocking on three years’ work.”Across the weekend at Traquair House, visitors can expect to find a range of onsite catering including a bar, live music sessions, film screenings, yoga and wellness sessions and family friendly activities.Riding at Muck n’ Mac Festival is open to anyone aged  and over and riders can bring a road bike, gravel mountain bike, or E-bike.And children can enjoy the weekend for free with a paying adult.“For me the point I’m most excited for is the Saturday evening after the first day’s riding,” said Cameron, who grew up in Heriot. “I’m looking forward to that sense of comradery – everyone’s been out on their bikes through the day, they’ve had that challenging day and come the evening time just everyone sitting down over a pint talking about their stories from the day and a bit of live music.”Cameron has always had a passion for biking, riding the trails around Innerleithen as a youngster.“I come from a cycling background myself,” he said, “I love cycling, it’s my passion. As a kid I was part of the Peebles Cycling Club..remove“[In] Peebles and Innerleithen is really where my cycling began. I grew up learning to ride mountain bikes and exploring.“It’s a fantastic area for riding bikes, it’s the trail I know best and I think it’s a great area for folks to be riding bikes.”Now, the -year-old is hoping that the first Muck n’ Mac Festival will not only be a fun event for the adult riders taking part, but will also encourage young people to get outside more.“The big driver is the cycling aspect,” he said. “To get more folk out riding bikes and to look at cycling from a dferent perspective.“I think there’s a lot of people, like myself for example, who were very much into the competitive side of it and kind of fell out of love with it.“So we’re trying to look at cycling from a dferent perspective and add extra elements to it, not so much the serious racing approach.“With the event being free for kids and the outdoor activities, just trying to get kids hooked on that outdoor type lestyle and getting more involved in the outdoors.”A full weekend riding ticket is £, a ticket for a single day riding is £, and a festival village pass is £.All tickets include the cost of camping at Traquair.For more information, visit: www.mucknmacfest

title: hygiene-rating-mcdonalds-galashiels
story: McDonalds is arguably the most popular fast-food chainin the world with thousands across the UK, including in Galashiels.We have one of those golden archesmeaning that we are never too far from a Big Mac or a Chicken Legend.But with each restaurant there comes a dferent standard to cleanliness and hygiene. And thanks to the Food Standards Agencywe get to look out what each of the hygiene ratings is for the dferent locations. The inspections are carried out by the local authority and findings are updated on the FSA website whenever there is a new inspection conducted by the council. Chicken. Big. Mac. It’s HERE! 🍗 🍔 😍 #ChickenBigMacpic xKCaQDULk— McDonalds UKFebruary , What the ratings mean:There are three dferent ratings in Scotland under the Food Hygiene Information Scheme.Pass means they meet the legal requirements for food hygiene.Improvement Required means the business didn’t meet the legal requirements and needs to make improvements.Exempt Premises means the business has been inspected by a local authority food safety officer, met the pass criteria, but don’t meet the criteria to be part of the scheme.  These businesses are low-risk to people’s health in terms of food safety and you perhaps wouldn’t normally think of them as a food business – for example, newsagents, chemist shops or visitor centres selling tins of biscuits.A new business or  there is a new owner, will be listed as "Awaiting Inspection" and will not have a food hygiene rating. How is Mcdonalds assessed Inspectors look at a few dferent key elements when assessing the hygiene of a restaurant including: How hygienically the food is handled- such as how its prepared, cooked, re-heated, cooled, and stored.The condition of the structure of the buildings – the cleanliness, layout, lighting, ventilation, and other facilities..removeHow the business manages what it does to make sure food is safe and so that the officer can be confident standards will be maintained in the future.The McDonalds in Galashiels hygiene ratings:Wilderhaugh​, GalashielsRating: PassLast inspected:  April
